awd_titl_txt: Travel: Improving the Utility of Haptic Feedback in Upper-Limb Prosthesis Control: Establishing user-centric guidelines for engineering innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide partial travel support for U.S. participants to attend the 2023 IEEE World Haptics Conference, which will take place July 10-13, 2023, in Delft, The Netherlands.  There is a divide between the reality of upper limb prostheses and the needs of prosthesis users, in terms of usability, reliability and cost. To help bridge this divide, the U.S. participants are organizing a workshop on “Improving the Utility of Haptic Feedback in Upper-Limb Prosthesis Control: Establishing User-Centric Guidelines for Engineering Innovation” at the 2023 IEEE World Haptics Conference, a premier international venue for exchanging ideas and innovations related to haptic (touch-based) technology. This workshop will bring together prosthesis users and prosthesis researchers to create guidelines for future research. Attendees will hear from leading researchers in the field, and actual prosthesis users, and will have an opportunity to engage in conversations that help shape the future of prosthesis technology. The goal of this travel support is to broaden participation in this workshop beyond established researchers, to include both prosthesis users and student researchers who may not have the research funds to support their own travel. 

The U.S. attendees include five prosthesis users, three prosthesis researchers, ten student researchers, and four workshop organizers. The outcome of this workshop will be a set of guiding principles that can be used by researchers in the community when designing future haptic feedback technologies for prosthesis use. In addition, these guidelines will be used to create a core set of study outcomes that can be used by researchers to standardize future research, and by clinicians and prosthesis users to compare and interpret future research advances. Priority consideration for student travel grants will be given to women and minority students. Workshop outcomes will be disseminated through the workshop website https://sites.google.com/gcloud.utah.edu/2023-whc-workshop/home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the travel cost associated with attending the workshop “Improving the Utility of Haptic Feedback in Upper-Limb Prosthesis Control: establishing user-centric guidelines for engineering innovation.” The workshop was held on July 10, 2023, at the 2023 IEEE World Haptics Conference in Delph, the Netherlands. 

The workshop was co-organized by Dr. Jeremy D. Brown (Johns Hopkins University), Dr. Edoardo Battaglia (University of Utah), Dr. Marcia K. O’Malley (Rice University), and Dr. Kristin Zhao (Mayo Clinic). The workshop featured short research presentations from Dr. Sliman Bensmaia (University of Chicago), Dr. Tamar Makin (University of Cambridge), Dr. Adam Spiers (Imperial College London), and Dr. Maria Fossati (Italian Institute of Technology). The workshop also featured a panel discussion with five prosthesis users, four of whom were able to attend the conference in person. Finally, the workshop featured seven student poster presentations.

The travel award fully sponsored the prosthesis users' attendance at the workshop in person and partially sponsored the workshop research presenters, student presenters, and workshop organizers.

The outcomes of the workshop were published in Science Robotics as part of a special issue on assistive and rehabilitative robotics. The article was co-authored by the workshop organizers as well as the prosthesis users who participated in the panel discussions.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2024
Modified by: Jeremy D Brown
